Key Arguments: No single entity can definitively determine what constitutes misinformation or disinformation due to the nuanced nature of most topics.
Fact-checking is inherently biased and can be misleading.
The bill poses a threat to free speech and democracy by potentially silencing dissenting voices.
Information, even if incorrect, is not inherently dangerous and can be countered with reasoned arguments.
Clause 6 (1) (c) of the bill, which allows for exemptions, could lead to misuse and corruption.
The concept of 'hatred' is subjective and should not be used to justify removing discourse.
Notable Quotes: There is no one person or group of people who hold the truth, and therefore determine if something is misinformation or disinformation.
This Bill is therefore, whether intentionally or not, an attack on free speech.
There is no danger in information. Information that is absolutely wrong is easily disputed with reasoned arguments.
To allow the possibility that some organisation could be exempt from the law is not equitable and allows for misuse and corruption.
